posts.cooked: Our team has encountered difficulties with Pathplanner throughout the entire season. Specifically, the problem occurs during the second path of the automatic system. This second path either moves in the opposite direction compared to the first path (for example, instead of moving backward plus, it moves forward plus to the right) or follows the same direction as the first path (for instance, it doesn't reverse when driven straight twice). While the first path functions correctly on its own, issues arise whenever additional paths are added to the system. These challenges have significantly restricted our ability to develop advanced autonomous solutions, compelling us to rely solely on pre-programmed systems. For those with experience or advice on this matter, your input would be greatly appreciated.

posts.name: Carlos Salazar
posts.cooked: Hello! Would you be able to upload your code onto GitHub?

If you examine the example code for pathplanner within its documentation, there exists a check for driver station.getalliance, allowing you to determine if the driver station's alliance is red or blue, so I would utilize that approach.
Here is our GitHub, hope this helps. Our updated code is not on main, it’s on ReleaseBranch

link_counts.title: GitHub - FRC-Team-3464/CHUM: chum, chumchum chum chum (to the Tums jingle)

posts.name: Carlos Salazar
posts.cooked:
First, I notice that the path flipping was set up incorrectly. WPILib sets up the blue-side origin for the field's coordinate system, and this same system is used by PathPlannerLib. When configuring the AutoBuilder, you're supposed to provide a BooleanSupplier that decides whether the path should be on the red side. What your code does is use !(alliance.get() == DriverStation.Alliance.Red), which flips the path to the opposite side every time. This explains why the path flips based on the alliance configuration now.

Looking at your follow-up questions:

1. What did you base your swerve code off of?
2. Did that code work in teleoperated mode without needing any sign changes or inverses?
3. Are the issues originating from autoChooser.getSelected() or are they due to manually compiling the paths?
I would not put a not in the check because checking for != blue is sufficient since it ensures the condition is met only when the value is blue.

posts.name: Carlos Salazar
posts.cooked: Just to clarify, the supplier should return `alliance.get() == DriverStation.Alliance.Red`. The snippet I shared earlier was directly from the uploaded codebase and is actually the opposite of what it should be.

The alliance flipping was just to make sure it wasn’t because of that. The code is based off of Team 364’s Swerve base. For teleop, controller values are inverted to match the coordinate system, but nothing else seems to be an issue. Issues arise when `autochooser.get(selected)` returns something unexpected.
Are you making your own auto chooser or are you using a pathplanner method for making an auto chooser?

posts.name: Carlos Salazar
posts.cooked:
I ran some of your auto paths in simulation, and everything on the PathPlanner end looks great (except for them flipping to the wrong side). What that leaves us with is trying to figure out what’s wrong in the codebase that’s causing issues with following the trajectories. A lot of times, going in the wrong direction is a consequence of improper gyro readings, and I’ve noticed quite a few things in the swerve subsystem that we can improve.

You’re currently using both SwerveDriveOdometry and SwerveDrivePoseEstimator since pose estimators work by maintaining their own odometry objects and “are designed to be drop-in replacements for the existing odometry classes” (WPILib Doc). I recommend replacing these by getting rid of the odometry object you’ve created and updating any methods to rely instead on the pose estimator. For example, replace SwerveOdometry.resetPosition() with poseEstimator.resetPosition(). Additionally, since SwervePose Estimator uses the odometry, you should eliminate it. Using getPose() in AutoBuilder will also enable PathPlanner to receive pose updates from the vision system.

The most significant issue is relying on gyro readings for heading estimation. For better or worse, the gyro headings are relative rather than absolute measures of the heading. When you call resetPose(), instead of updating the gyro to reflect the new rotation, the pose estimator offsets every subsequent measurement taken from the gyro. To address this, create a new method that retrieves the current heading from the pose estimator and use this method in drive() instead of getYaw() when converting field-relative translations to robot-relative ones. However, it’s crucial to continue using getYaw() to update the pose estimator in periodic().

link_counts.title: Pose Estimators — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Mete Karadeniz
posts.cooked: We had a similar issue. We were adjusting the robot pose based on real-time calculations and ensuring all paths ended.

Sorry for the late reply; our team hasn’t had much time to meet recently. Our fix addressed the issue where the path inversion wasn’t working correctly. However, we’ve encountered a new problem since then. After rerunning the tests, the robot followed the X,Y coordinates in the path but didn’t rotate. When observing the robot, its wheels weren’t aligning with the path either. To resolve this, we’ve uploaded an updated code version under the “ChiefDelphiAutos” branch on GitHub. Thank you for your assistance.
